Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Operating Software for Humanoid Robots

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in the development of the Conductor software. Conductor is a programming framework designed to act as a controller development tool for high degree of freedom systems. These are systems with many mobile joints, surfaces, or sensors. Specifically it is focused on controlling legged robots, although it is general enough to work with other complex systems. It is differentiated from other robotics frameworks in the way that it provides hardware access to users. Within Conductor access to hardware is provided through an abstraction that closely mirrors the mathematical notations used by scientists and engineers in the field. This allows them to easily transition from theoretical calculations of a robot's expected performance to experimental validation on actual hardware. Such an approach can save valuable time and resources during robot design. The design also allows for controllers to be ported easily between robots with similar physical forms.
The implementation of the system was performed by American researchers working at, and in collaboration with HuboLab, a South Korean robotics laboratory at KAIST University. The primary development target for this software was the Hubo robot, a bipedal adult-sized humanoid robot that has become a collaboration between a number of American and Korean research institutes. The infrastructure being developed for this project will be deployed at Drexel University. There, it will allow broader access to humanoid robotics technology for American researchers. The Conductor software will play a key role in allowing remote access to the infrastructure by researchers around the country. It will also facilitate the rapid design and prototyping of humanoid robot control algorithms. Additionally, the software will be provided under an open source license to the public after it has been presented at the Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS) conference in September 2011.
